back: Layout is the arrangement of visual elements like text, images, and white space on a page or screen to communicate a message.

front: What does alignment refer to in design?
back: Alignment refers to how design elements are placed in relation to one another, helping make the layout look clean and organized.
Composition is the arrangement of design elements to create harmony and artistic coherence.

front: What is balance in visual design?
back: Balance refers to how visual weight is distributed in a design, using symmetrical or asymmetrical arrangements to create equilibrium.

front: What does scale refer to in design?
back: Scale compares the size of one design element to another.
Hierarchy establishes the importance of elements, making sure the most important information stands out first.
Contrast is the use of visual differences like color, size, and shape to distinguish elements and improve readability.
White space is the empty area around design elements, helping create breathing room and clarity.
UI stands for User Interface and includes all visual and interactive elements like icons, text, and buttons.
UX stands for User Experience and focuses on how a user feels when using a product or service.
A design brief is a document outlining the goals, objectives, and requirements of a project.
Vector-based design uses mathematical formulas to create graphics that can be resized without losing quality.
Prototyping is the process of creating an interactive model of a product or interface.

front: What is good contrast in design?
back: Good contrast ensures readable text and visual clarity, meeting WCAG guidelines like 4.5:1 for normal text.
Visual hierarchy is the organization of elements to guide the viewerâ€™s eye in a logical and intentional order.
Responsive images adjust to fit the screen size across devices, improving usability and appearance.
Progressive enhancement ensures basic content and functionality are accessible to all users, regardless of browser or device.
User-centered design prioritizes the needs, preferences, and limitations of users to create intuitive experiences.
User research involves studying your users to understand their behaviors, needs, and pain points.
Exit interviews are surveys for users who cancel accounts to understand reasons for leaving and reduce churn.
User testing captures real user interactions to assess usability and identify areas for improvement.
A/B testing is launching a new feature to a subset of users and using data to evaluate its impact.
User requirements define what a product must do, based on user research, industry standards, or stakeholder input.
Progressive disclosure shows only relevant content based on current activity to reduce cognitive load.

front: What is deferred or lazy registration?
back: It allows users to interact with an app before creating an account, reducing barriers to entry.
Dark mode is a UI theme with dark backgrounds and light text, using desaturated colors for accessibility.
Breadcrumbs are navigation aids that show users their location in a site's hierarchy.
A card is a compact content block in UI design, best kept simple and supported by high-quality visuals.
Infinite scroll loads more content as the user scrolls. A 'load more' button can improve user control.
A modal is a pop-up overlay that focuses user attention. Clicking outside to close is a common best practice.

front: What is progress indication in forms?
back: Progress indicators show users how far along they are in a process and can allow navigation between steps.

front: What is a shopping cart in UI?
back: A shopping cart lets users view selected items. It should be visible, use clear icons, and include a checkout CTA.
Figma is a cloud-based UI/UX design tool for collaboration, vector editing, layouts, and feedback.
Sketch is a popular design tool known for its simplicity and use in prototyping and web design.
Adobe XD is a vector-based UI/UX tool with tight integration with Adobe apps like Photoshop and Illustrator.
Canva is a user-friendly design tool ideal for beginners to create graphics, videos, and presentations.
